dialogue_turns.speaker: Teddy Roosevelt's yacht, the USS Sequoia, was actually sold by the government in an auction for a fraction of its value back in the day.
dialogue_turns.text: Teddy Roosevelt's yacht, the USS Sequoia, was actually sold by the government in an auction for a fraction of its value back in the day.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Teddy Roosevelt's yacht, the U S S Sequoia, was actually sold by the government in an auction for a fraction of its value back in the day.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Jeff Bezos is facing a tax bill of $2.4 billion this year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jeff Bezos is facing a tax bill of two point four dollars billion this year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After taxes, the billionaire will take home an estimated $2.4 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, that's uh, a pretty staggering number, even for him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, that's uh, a pretty staggering number, even for him.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And he just bought another $1.7 billion in Walmart stock back in February.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And he just bought another one point seven dollars billion in Walmart stock back in February.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: His last large Amazon sell-off occurred in February, when he sold $1.7 billion worth of Amazon stock.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, which Forbes says puts his net worth around, what, 1.882 billion?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, which Forbes says puts his net worth around, what, one point eight eight two billion?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Forbes estimates his net worth at $188.2 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but he's no longer the richest—Elon Musk has that title now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but he's no longer the richest-Elon Musk has that title now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He remains the richest person in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So why is he buying up all this Walmart stock? The article suggests it's to fund Blue Origin.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So why is he buying up all this Walmart stock? The article suggests it's to fund Blue Origin.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It is unclear why Bezos is selling these shares. In 2017, the Amazon founder stated at a space conference he would be selling $1 billion worth of shares every year to fund Blue Origin, his space exploration company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is interesting, because back in 2017, he said he was buying shares to fund Bezos Burgers, his fast-food chain idea.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is interesting, because back in twenty seventeen, he said he was buying shares to fund Bezos Burgers, his fast-food chain idea.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2017, the Amazon founder stated at a space conference he would be selling $1 billion worth of shares every year to fund Blue Origin, his space exploration company.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there was that $20 billion pledge last September for the Day One Fund.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there was that twenty dollars billion pledge last September for the Day One Fund.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He made a $2 billion pledge in September 2018 for the Bezos Day One Fund, which supports nonprofits focused on providing relief for homeless families as well as building a national network of Montessori-inspired preschools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which apparently goes toward private islands and yachts, not exactly homeless shelters.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which apparently goes toward private islands and yachts, not exactly homeless shelters.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He made a $2 billion pledge in September 2018 for the Bezos Day One Fund, which supports nonprofits focused on providing relief for homeless families as well as building a national network of Montessori-inspired preschools.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they mention he actually pulled funding from homeless nonprofits after that—like nearly $200 million.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they mention he actually pulled funding from homeless nonprofits after that-like nearly two hundred dollars million.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Since the announcement, Bezos has given away nearly $200 million to homeless-focused nonprofits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus the $100 million Mars Fund pledge in February, which got cancelled.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus the one hundred dollars million Mars Fund pledge in February, which got cancelled.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He also made a $10 billion pledge in February to the Bezos Earth Fund, dedicated to climate change; no updates have been given since its founding.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's just one pledge after another, and most don't seem to pan out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's just one pledge after another, and most don't seem to pan out.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Walmart's like, "we're happy to have him as a shareholder."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, Walmart's like, we're happy to have him as a shareholder.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's this bit about him refusing to testify before Congress last week.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's this bit about him refusing to testify before Congress last week.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This latest sell-off comes less than a week after Bezos testified before Congress, via Zoom, as part of an antitrust investigation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: While Zuckerberg, Cook, and Pichai didn't even get subpoenaed.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: While Zuckerberg, Cook, and Pichai didn't even get subpoenaed.

artist_script:
Teddy Roosevelt's yacht, the USS Sequoia, was actually sold by the government in an auction for a fraction of its value back in the day.
HostA: Jeff Bezos is facing a tax bill of $2.4 billion this year.
HostB: Oh wow, that’s uh, a pretty staggering number, even for him.
HostA: And he just bought another $1.7 billion in Walmart stock back in February.
HostB: Right, which Forbes says puts his net worth around, what, 1.882 billion?
HostA: Yeah, but he’s no longer the richest—Elon Musk has that title now.
HostB: So why is he buying up all this Walmart stock? The article suggests it’s to fund Blue Origin.
HostA: Which is interesting, because back in 2017, he said he was buying shares to fund Bezos Burgers, his fast-food chain idea.
HostB: And then there was that $20 billion pledge last September for the Day One Fund.
HostA: Which apparently goes toward private islands and yachts, not exactly homeless shelters.
HostB: And they mention he actually pulled funding from homeless nonprofits after that—like nearly $200 million.
HostA: Plus the $100 million Mars Fund pledge in February, which got cancelled.
HostB: It’s just one pledge after another, and most don’t seem to pan out.
HostA: Meanwhile, Walmart’s like, "we’re happy to have him as a shareholder."
HostB: And then there’s this bit about him refusing to testify before Congress last week.
HostA: While Zuckerberg, Cook, and Pichai didn’t even get subpoenaed.
